Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Seismic Response to the 2016 M5.8 Pawnee Earthquake
Award.AbstractNarration:
Induced earthquakes, or seismicity caused by human activity such as wastewater injection or secondary oil recovery, have been increasing in the midwestern United States since 2009. The state of Oklahoma has become known as "the new earthquake capital", with earthquake rates of M>3 exceeding those of California in the last few years. The 3 September 2016 Mw5.8 Pawnee, Oklahoma earthquake occurred within the region of induced seismicity, near wastewater disposal wells, and was the largest earthquake ever recorded within the state. The earthquake occurred five years after the second largest earthquake, the similarly sized Mw5.7 November 2011 Prague earthquake. Near Pawnee, local residents reported strong ground-shaking, damage to houses, cracks on the ground, and concerns about safety. Students from Cornell University and Colombia University, in collaboration with local universities including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma State University, and University of Tulsa, actively participated in the rapid deployment of 25 seismic stations around the epicentral region. Students of the institutions involved have been actively involved in learning about sensors, network designs, and earthquake physics.

The main fault the ruptured during the Pawnee event was an unmapped fault intersecting mapped Labette Fault, which has hosted a significant number of aftershocks include the largest aftershock (M3.9). The aftershock sequence and related seismic activity in the region that has been recorded since the rapid (within 2 days) deployment of seismic instrumentation will help study aftershocks and the likely triggered seismicity on the regional fault systems. In the coming weeks, we will deploy an additional 20 short-period stations that will record data for 12 months. This combined network will provide information on fault structure, aftershock decay, duration, and interaction with injection rate variations. The data will help to understand the characteristics of faults that host large damaging earthquakes, and will help to assess earthquake hazards in Oklahoma and the midcontinent. The broader impact of this rapid deployment will help understand the regional tectonic framework in northern Oklahoma and may elucidate the relationship between this recent seismic activity with the fluid injection activities in the region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mw 5.8 Pawnee earthquake (September 3, 2016) is the largest earthquake recorded in Oklahoma. The epicenter area was surrounded by waste-water injection wells. The rapid aftershock observation of this earthquake is important for understanding the physics of the induced seismicity and the interaction between solid earth, faulting system, and injection fluid. With this project, PIs at the University of Oklahoma deployed 9 2Hz geophones and 20 L22 short-period seismometers, and observed seismic motion including aftershocks for one year. All stations are three components, and the L22 sensors were provided by IRIS PASSCAL. The data recorded by L22 sensors have been archived in the IRIS data management center with network code of Y7, and the 2Hz geophones will be uploaded shortly. Also, OGS creates a webpage to visualize the recorded data in real time. This project is a collaboration research with four universities, and the other universities deployed more than 12 stations, some of which have strong motion sensors.

The field work including deployment, maintenance, and collection of sensors takes total more than 10 days. For the deployment and sensor collection, undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Oklahoma participated: Stephen Marsh, Jianhang Yin, Jiewen Zhang, Colin Pennington, Jackson Haffener, Yan Qin, Murphy Cassel, and Bailey E. Hein.

Using this recoded dataset and previously deployed USGS/OGS regional networks, the PIs and collaborators published a paper presenting an idea of nucleation physics of the Pawnee earthquake from Scientific Reports. In addition, the PIs gave talks/presentations at major conferences including SSA and AGU about this dataset and results obtained. Two of main figures related to the results are attached in this report.


 

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2018
Modified by: Norimitsu Nakata

The rapid aftershock observation of this earthquake is important for understanding the physics of the induced seismicity and the interaction between solid earth, faulting system, and injection fluid. With this project, PIs at the University of Oklahoma deployed 9 2Hz geophones and 20 L22 short-period seismometers, and observed seismic motion including aftershocks for one year. All stations are three components, and the L22 sensors were provided by IRIS PASSCAL. The data recorded by L22 sensors have been archived in the IRIS data management center with network code of Y7, and the 2Hz geophones will be uploaded shortly. Also, OGS creates a webpage to visualize the recorded data in real time. This project is a collaboration research with four universities, and the other universities deployed more than 12 stations, some of which have strong motion sensors. The field work including deployment, maintenance, and collection of sensors takes total more than 10 days. For the deployment and sensor collection, undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Oklahoma participated: Stephen Marsh, Jianhang Yin, Jiewen Zhang, Colin Pennington, Jackson Haffener, Yan Qin, Murphy Cassel, and Bailey E. Using this recoded dataset and previously deployed USGS/OGS regional networks, the PIs and collaborators published a paper presenting an idea of nucleation physics of the Pawnee earthquake from Scientific Reports. In addition, the PIs gave talks/presentations at major conferences including SSA and AGU about this dataset and results obtained.
